clean_story:
Faster alone.  Smarter alone.
The phrase "group decision" assumes many minds outperform one. But studies show groups often choose worse than their best member working solo.
Imagine a school of fish dodging a predator. Individually, each fish reacts in 0. 1 seconds— but in a group, they hesitate, matching the slowest member’s 0. 3-second delay.
Three flaws emerge:
1. The loudest voice wins. Experiments with jury deliberations reveal 70% of final verdicts mirror the first speaker’s opinion— even if later facts contradict it.
2. Shared ignorance feels safe. In 1950s psychology tests, groups guessed a jar’s candy count. Alone, estimates varied widely— but together, they converged on the average guess, which was always wrong.
3. Responsibility diffuses. NASA’s Challenger disaster traces to a group approving launch despite engineer warnings. Post-mortems found no single person felt accountable for the final "go. "
Solutions? Silent brainstorming first— then debate. Or assign a "devil’s advocate" to argue against the group’s lean.
Three related subjects are herd behavior in markets, how juries reach verdicts, and why lone inventors outpace committees.
